overview: Your rights as a disabled parent, entitlement to benefits and other financial help and support from your council
title: Disabled parents

table.body:
##Starting a family

As a [disabled person](/definition-of-disability-under-the-equality-act-2010 "Definition of disability"), you have the right to make your own mind up about becoming a parent. 

You shouldn't be denied fertility treatment because you're disabled.

Your health and well-being are factors in adoption assessments but you mustn't be automatically disqualified because you are disabled.

##Your child(ren)

Your child shouldn't be identified as 'in need' because you're disabled (although this could be a factor). A child-in-need assessment should only be carried out if there are concerns about your child's well-being.

^A 'child in need' is a child under 17 whose health and development is likely to be made significantly worse without support.^ 

The Human Rights Act 1998 is relevant to disabled parents, eg:

- Article 12: The right to marry and to found a family - social care services and health providers should take all reasonable steps to help you have a family including giving advice and support before and after your child is born
table.title: Your rights

table.body:
You could get extra help at home as a disabled parent. Ask for a [health and social care assessment](/apply-needs-assessment-social-services "Apply for a needs assessment by social services") to work out what help you need. You can get the assessment before you have your child.

If you get [Disability Living Allowance (DLA)](/dla-disability-living-allowance-benefit "Disability Living Allowance"), the amount of benefit you're entitled to may change if you have a child. Contact the Disability Living Allowance helpline. 

$C
**Disability Living Allowance helpline**  
**Telephone:** 08457 123 456  
**Textphone:** 08457 22 44 33  
$C

Your [local council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} must make sure disabled people are supported in their family and parental roles. They can support you in several areas, eg visiting your child's school.

##Equipment
The Disabled Living Foundation has information on equipment for disabled parents.

$D
[Download Disabled Living Foundation - Disability, pregnancy and parenthood equipment factsheet (PDF, 180KB)'](http://www.dlf.org.uk/factsheets/Disability_pregnancy_and_parenthood.pdf "Download 'Disabled Living Foundation - Disability, pregnancy and parenthood equipment factsheet' (PDF, 180KB)")
$D

##Parenting classes
[Parenting UK](http://www.parentinguk.org/ "Parenting UK"){:rel="external"} holds classes on the skills you'll need as a disabled parent. Classes must be accessible.
